body.p: Alhough the Jenkins servers provide a complete validation service for any modifications to the TEI project, developers may also like to check their modifications locally before committing them to the server, as an optional additional step in the development process. A local build of TEI P5 may also be useful during development and experimentation.
This document describes briefly how to build a software environment for such a purpose. It assumes that you have already installed subversion, and that you have plenty of disk space.

div.head: Ubuntu or other Debian-based Linux distributions
div.p: The following procedure has been tested on a fresh installation of Ubuntu 14.04. Some modification may be needed for other distributions.
Open a terminal window and type the following shell commands :

list.item: Create folders to hold the source files. I like to keep the TEI Source and the TEI Stylesheets separate but this is not important. mkdir TEI-Source Stylesheets

Use subversion to check out a fresh copy of the TEI and Stylesheets source trees and place them in the folders you just created svn co https://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/tei/trunk TEI-Source svn co https://github.com/TEIC/Stylesheets Stylesheets You can of course use git rather than svn to get a copy of the Stylesheets if you prefer. Or you can elect not to maintain a local copy of the Stylesheets at all, but simply install the tei-xsl package from the Oxford repository (see below).

You must have some sort of functioning java before trying to install the Stylesheets on your local system (you won't get far without them). We recommend something like this : sudo apt-get install openjdk-7-* cd Stylesheets/trunk; sudo make install

You now need to install a mixed bag of XML tools since the build process uses several different XML validators. Start with the following: sudo apt-get install jing trang ant libxml2-utils curl The easiest way to get the remainder is from the debian repository at Oxford, though you could also get them individually elsewhere, To use the Oxford repo, you need to add it to your sources.list and install its public key. The procedure is described at

The two remaining required validators (onvdl and rnv) are not available in package form from the usual repositories, so installing them requires you either to use the unsupported and experimental archive at Oxford, or to do some more fiddling about. First, if you are using the Oxford repo, sudo apt-get install onvdl rnv is all you need.

Alternatively, you can download and install the ONVDL JAFR files as follows wget www.oxygenxml.com/InstData/Editor/onvdl/onvdl-2007517.zip; unzip onvdl-2007517.zip ; sudo mv onvdl-2007517/bin /usr/share/onvdl . You may then need to set up a suitable command to run the jar file. For example: sudo cat 'java -Xss2048k -jar /usr/share/onvdl/onvdl.jar ${1+"$@"}' > /usr/bin/onvdl

On a 64 bit architecture, you will in any case need to build rnv from source because the rnv package in the Oxford repo contains only the 32 bit version, which does not work. sudo apt-get install libexpat1-dev; wget http://ftp.davidshen.net/PreTI/RNV/RNV.ZIP; unzip ~/Downloads/RNV.ZIP; cd ~/Downloads/rnv-1.7.8; make; sudo mv rnv /usr/bin This step should not be necessary on a 32-bit machine. Or after the package gets updated.

Now you're ready to boogie. cd TEI-Source; make clean; make will delete the results of any previous attempts, and build everything from fresh using whatever is in your TEI-Source directory. It will also run all the testfiles, and generate a new HTML source tree for P5. For other outputs, see below.

div.p: You can of course run parts of the Makefile separately. For example, run "make check" to run the TEI test suite; "make validate" to validate the P5 source; make exemplars to check that all the TEI explars still work; run "make ebook" or "make mobi" to produce an Ebook or Mobi version of the Guidelines respectively. "make pdf" will try to build the fancy PDF version of the Guidelines, but it won't get far unless you have a working LiveTex environment and the requisite fonts. (see below)

div.head: Producing PDF on Ubuntu
div.p: The commands teitopdf and teitoslides expect to find LiveTex installed on your system, as does the command "make pdf". This means you need to install the following packages: sudo apt-get install texlive texlive-xetex texlive-latex-extra
You'll also probably need something to read the PDF: try sudo apt-get install evince adobereader-en
And you will also need several fonts, especially if you aim to produce the PDF version of P5. sudo apt-get install ttf-linux-libertine ttf-kochi-mincho should do it.
